speaker: Claude
text: That one seemed to work… We’re almost done! Let’s go, my friend.

speaker: Nemesis
text: You are a foolish child.

speaker: Claude
text: Tough talk from a guy who's lived too long. Allow me to fix that!

speaker: Nemesis
text: You are all pathetic weaklings! You lack the courage to challenge me in lone combat.

speaker: Claude
text: Yet we have the strength to scale the walls between us, to reach our hands in friendship, so we can open our true hearts to one another!

speaker: Claude
text: That's how we win!

speaker: Claude
text: Future historians will refer to this day as the new dawn of Fódlan. Of that, I have no doubt.

speaker: Claude
text: It's up to you now Teach. As for my path...

speaker: Raphael
text: What? Not enough left for seconds? I'm barely half full!

speaker: Cyril
text: Ya eat too much anyways, Raphael. Supplies are running low, so you're just gonna have to deal with it.

speaker: Ignatz
text: You've always been so level-headed, Cyril. Now that you've grown up, you're even more that way.

speaker: Cyril
text: Maybe it's just that the rest of you haven't grown enough. You could work harder at being reliable.

speaker: Raphael
text: I can't grow if I can't eat!

speaker: Hilda
text: I have some good news for my hungry friends... We got a reply from Judith!

speaker: Hilda
text: Mr. Leader Man has called a meeting about it. Hurry up, everyone!

speaker: Claude
text: We finally received a reply from Judith. The Hero of Daphnel has agreed to support us with soldiers and supplies.

speaker: Raphael
text: She's gonna give us food? She really is a hero!

speaker: Cyril
text: Maybe Raphael will simmer down now.

speaker: Claude
text: Now, regarding where we're going to receive the delivery...

speaker: Judith
text: As this is a request from none other than the leader of the Alliance, I wish that I could send troops at once. However... Openly marshaling soldiers within my territory could provoke other members of the Alliance. Therefore, I will secretly gather troops in Ailell, the Valley of Torment. Will your group be able to receive the soldiers at this location? From there, it should be safe to return to the monastery by following the border between the Alliance and the Kingdom.

speaker: Byleth
text: Ailell, the Valley of Torment...

speaker: Claude
text: Ailell is on the border between the Daphnel territory and the Kingdom. It'll make sense when we get there, but it's a peculiar region.

speaker: Marianne
text: I recall there being a scary legend about it...

speaker: Claude
text: In any case, if we use that valley, we shouldn't have to worry about being noticed by other Alliance lords.

speaker: Alliance Soldier
text: Ailell, the Valley of Torment...

speaker: Claude
text: You know… I'd never have been recognized as the legitimate heir to House Riegan without Judith's recommendation… Feels like I'm digging myself deeper and deeper in debt to the Hero of Daphnel, but what do you do? It's all been worth it. After all, we need the Daphnel army for our next move. It's possible we'll have to deal with our enemy sooner than later. Be prepared, Teach.

speaker: Lorenz
text: The bridge that links Alliance and Empire lands is currently under the occupation of the Imperial army. In other words, the Empire can choose to invade the Alliance whenever they wish. I want you to understand that my father does not support the Empire to antagonize House Riegan. He does it to deprive them of an easy excuse to cross that bridge.

speaker: Raphael
text: Sharing her food with us for nothing in return? Judith really is a great person! She's more like a goddess than the goddess is!

speaker: Byleth
text: She is very much like a goddess.

speaker: Raphael
text: I never met her, so I don't know for sure, but she must be beautiful and kind.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not sure about that.

speaker: Raphael
text: No? Well, she could be a demon for all I care, so long as she feeds me!

speaker: Ignatz
text: The Valley of Torment... I'd heard of it, but I never expected to go there. It's exciting! I wonder what the landscape is like.

speaker: Byleth
text: It sounds dangerous.

speaker: Ignatz
text: It probably is dangerous, but I still want to get there and see it as soon as I can.

speaker: Byleth
text: It sounds painful.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Hm, that is an interesting point... The name does seem to suggest that.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Ailell, the Valley of Torment, lies on the border of three noble territories. The Kingdom's Fraldarius and Galatea families, and the Alliance's Daphnel family. In the Fraldarius lands to the north, the former Kingdom army and new duke's army are fighting.

speaker: Marianne
text: Valley of Torment... Valley of Torment...

speaker: Byleth
text: Something wrong?

speaker: Marianne
text: I once read a book full of legends surrounding Ailell, but I can't seem to remember...

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you chanting some sort of curse?

speaker: Marianne
text: N-no... I'm trying to remember the legends surrounding Ailell...

speaker: Hilda
text: My big brother told me stories of Judith's bravery. With just one look, she tamed a runaway horse that nobody else had been able to touch. When an Almyran general provoked her, she talked him into a tearful apology. She's spectacular. I wish she'd fight alongside us.

speaker: Leonie
text: You're not a teacher anymore, and we're not your students, but everyone still calls you Professor. Is there something you'd rather be called?

speaker: Byleth
text: Professor is fine.

speaker: Leonie
text: Guess that's what we're used to, huh? All right.

speaker: Byleth
text: Call me by my name.

speaker: Leonie
text: Oh? All right, then. I'll call you - ugh. Nope! Sorry, can't do it. Too weird.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Some day we will take the Imperial capital. It is odd to think that I will be invading the very city that I once called home. Ah, that is still a ways off. I will prepare for our journey to Ailell.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I never do get used to the sight of blood. It always makes me feel as if I might faint. Have I never told you that? Huh. Oh well. I hope this war ends soon. I dislike being lightheaded because other people are bleeding everywhere. Though the thought of working hard for it does sound like quite a pain...

speaker: Caspar
text: I didn't think we'd end up fighting Randolph... He's my uncle. Well, not by blood, so... I guess I can handle it.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm still worried about you.

speaker: Byleth
text: You're very resolute.

speaker: Caspar
text: Don't worry about me. I'm ready for anything.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Ailell, the Valley of Torment? What kind of a name for a place is that? It sounds scary. Do I really have to go with you? Hey, um, here's an idea... Maybe let the recluse stay home and hold the fort!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Hey, Professor, thanks for your hard work again! Nothing to report today! Was I convincing? Was it like he was standing right in front of you? Some things are the same as they were five years ago, but I guess a lot more has changed...

speaker: Petra
text: Since the past, I have learned much of the language of Fódlan. But speaking the Fódlan language still gives me difficulty. I can understand, read, and write with nearly perfection now. But understanding and speaking are...fruits of a different color.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's part of your charm

speaker: Petra
text: I have gratitude for you, Professor. I hope that I will have fluency one day.

speaker: Byleth
text: Everyone has a weak spot.

speaker: Petra
text: Yes. I will keep practicing more.

speaker: Felix
text: Some in Faerghus believe Dimitri is still alive. My father is one such eccentric. Hmph, they can't accept reality. Dimitri is dead. He's not coming back.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Ailell, the Valley of Torment. Aw, man... I really do not want to go there.

speaker: Byleth
text: Pull yourself together.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Professor, have you ever been to Ailell? If you had, you'd know.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why not?

speaker: Sylvain
text: That place is crazy hot! For guys like me who grew up somewhere cold? Man... It's gonna be rough. Though, I guess that climate will keep our enemies at bay.

speaker: Mercedes
text: We may not be students anymore, but it's still important to read. We might even learn something that's useful for our next battle.

speaker: Byleth
text: Studying is important.

speaker: Mercedes
text: I couldn't agree more! I hope the Officers Academy reopens when the war is over.

speaker: Byleth
text: Training is important too.

speaker: Mercedes
text: I suppose that may be true. I always try my best at both.

speaker: Mercedes
text: It's a shame the monastery was ruined but...At least the books are still intact!

speaker: Annette
text: Professor, how do Claude and Judith know each other? I hear there are still quarrels within the Alliance… This generous offer of soldiers and supplies seems a little too good to be true. I mean, it’s also really impressive, but I’m just a little worried, I suppose…

speaker: Ingrid
text: My family, the Galateas, are an offshoot of the Daphnel family. The family split in half when two brothers quarreled over an inheritance. Despite blood relations, the families lived apart from one another, so the relationship has been distant and somewhat estranged. I’m not so much acquainted with Judith, the head of House Daphnel.

speaker: Seteth
text: Meeting reinforcements in the Valley of Torment seems an astute decision to me. In that land of oppressive heat, it is unlikely that we will be disturbed. It also means we will need to contend with those harsh conditions ourselves, however. Best ensure we are well prepared.

speaker: Flayn
text: It has been only five years, yet so much has changed. Half of the Kingdom has fallen to the Empire. Skirmishes are rife throughout the Alliance. Despite such tumult, we look upon the same sky, unchanged by the storm happening beneath it.

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you wish you could return to those days?

speaker: Flayn
text: Yes, it would be nice, I suppose. Things were... simpler then. Or so they seemed to be, at the time.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's true - it's just like it was all those years ago.

speaker: Flayn
text: Indeed. I gazed up at the same sky with Mother and Father. It does not feel so long ago at all. Wait, but how would you know, Professor?

speaker: Hanneman
text: The monastery repairs have made solid progress. Most excellent news. When we first returned here, I was unsure what we were going to do with the ruins of this place... But if we can get the cathedral rebuilt, we'll have it looking just like the old times soon enough.

speaker: Manuela
text: Hearing that an old student has died cuts me right to the heart... As this war with the Empire continues, we'll see more of it, Professor. We have a duty to fight alongside our former students. We taught them how to fight, after all. Now, let's help them win!

speaker: Alois
text: Even though we're getting reinforcements, we should still be prepared for the worst. Never shirk your training, no matter what. To practice, I'm going to chop something up with my sword. Unless you'd like to train together! Care to spar?

speaker: Catherine
text: I've heard people talk about the Hero of Daphnel. If the stories of her courage are true, no one will be able to stand against us. In different circumstances, I'd have wanted to try crossing swords with her. Right now we have to focus on getting to those reinforcements. Let's hope nothing goes wrong.

speaker: Shamir
text: There are enemy spies around. Remain vigilant. Capture anyone who seems suspicious.

speaker: Byleth
text: To kill them?

speaker: Shamir
text: What else would we do with them?

speaker: Byleth
text: All right, I will.

speaker: Shamir
text: I'm glad you understand. I'm counting on you.

speaker: Cyril
text: Gotta clean out the storerooms, tend the flowers, do the washing, dust the library...

speaker: Byleth
text: That sounds like a lot of work.

speaker: Cyril
text: Well, it's my job, ya know? Gotta do your job.

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you need any help?

speaker: Cyril
text: Nah, this is my job. Lady Rhea herself gave it do me.

speaker: Cyril
text: Even if Lady Rhea's not here right now, I still gotta do my duty.

speaker: Cyril
text: Like you. You gotta have other stuff you oughta be doing, yeah?

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Is everyone setting out on a big campaign? Not exactly? Ah, so you're meeting up with the reinforcements. We'll, you can leave guarding this place to me! I'll keep an eye out for anything suspicious!

speaker: Hilda
text: Ugh, why is it so hot? I'm getting all sweaty!

speaker: Raphael
text: Don't be a wimp! Anything's worth it for more food supplies.

speaker: Leonie
text: Move over, Raphael. Somehow you make the heat even worse.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Let's stay calm, everyone. Once we meet up with Judith's soldiers, we can go right back home.

speaker: Marianne
text: Oh, I finally remembered! The legend goes that this valley was born from the wrath of the goddess...

speaker: Marianne
text: They say a pillar of light poured from the heavens and completely burned away the forest that used to be here...

speaker: Claude
text: So you're telling me the goddess, who is supposed to be benevolent, burned a forest to a crisp? Typical.

speaker: Marianne
text: That's what the legend would have us believe. But it's not recorded in any of the scriptures...

speaker: Claude
text: Either it's completely made up, or the goddess is some kind of monster.

speaker: Cyril
text: Huh? Is that...

speaker: Lorenz
text: The time for idle chatter is over, Claude. Look over there.

speaker: Claude
text: Ah, has someone come to greet us?

speaker: Byleth
text: Enemies?

speaker: Byleth
text: Allies?

speaker: Lorenz
text: That banner does not bear the Daphnel Crest.

speaker: Claude
text: If memory serves... That's the Crest of House Rowe, formerly lords of the Kingdom. They joined the Empire's side without hesitation during the coup. And now here they are, lying in wait for us.

speaker: Shamir
text: Damn... I thought we had disposed of all the spies...

speaker: Lorenz
text: House Rowe is mediocre and vulgar, but I hear their knights are powerful.

speaker: Hilda
text: What about the Daphnel soldiers? You don't think...

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm worried about Judith.

speaker: Claude
text: Judith will be fine. It would take a lot more than that to take her down.

speaker: Byleth
text: We need to break through their ranks.

speaker: Claude
text: We've already been spotted, so there's no time to come up with a brilliant plan.

speaker: Claude
text: Everyone, prepare for battle! I leave the command in your capable hands, my friend.

speaker: Gwendal
text: The Valley of Torment... Perhaps a good place to finish off my life as a knight. Only if that puny force of children is able to kill me, of course...

speaker: Claude
text: So, their general must be that stubborn-looking old man. He looks like he wouldn't even forgive a sobbing child. It's good we came armed for the occasion. Care to find Judith?

speaker: Claude
text: Flames are flaring everywhere and burning people where they stand... Ailell is a terrible place. Everyone, if you don't want to get burned to a crisp, watch your step!

speaker: Gwendal
text: The Crest of Flames? Ha! Quite full of themselves, aren't they?

speaker: Ashe
text: Just as I thought - the professor's army. But it's too late to back out now. In Lonato's place, I have to do my duty.

speaker: Judith
text: Oh, old Gwendal is here. And he doesn't look to be an ally...

speaker: Gwendal
text: Oh, the Hero of Daphnel is here! I'll expect more from her than the young ones...

speaker: Defeat Conditions
text: All of your units fall in battle, or Judith is defeated.

speaker: Kingdom Soldier
text: Here we go! Attack them from both sides!

speaker: Judith
text: So, you're finally here, supreme leader. And something extra has tagged along.

speaker: Claude
text: Sorry, Judith. That rat got away.

speaker: Judith
text: Hey, don't worry. And here, you should have this. Perhaps it will come in handy.

speaker: Gwendal
text: Does a whelp like you really expect to kill me? I am Gwendal, the Gray Lion, a knight by the hand of Count Rowe! Do your worst!

speaker: Gwendal
text: Ah, so I have found a place to die... Young ones... I thank you...

speaker: Claude
text: That old man must have been struggling with the position he found himself in... It's time to gather ourselves and pull back our troops.

speaker: Judith
text: To think we'd get into a scrap here of all places. We're lucky we all made it out alive.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm sorry for involving you in this.

speaker: Judith
text: Don't worry about it. In this day and age, it's a miracle I've been unscathed this long.

speaker: Byleth
text: I can see why they call you a hero.

speaker: Judith
text: Well, that's ancient history.

speaker: Judith
text: Anyway, long time no see, Professor! Are you still watching this boy's back?

speaker: Claude
text: Can you quit calling me a boy in front of everyone? I'm the leader of the Alliance now. It's not proper-

speaker: Judith
text: Not proper, is it? Says the leader who has neglected Alliance territory for years. If you're really the Master Tactician, you should go back to working quietly at whatever little desk you do your planning on.

speaker: Claude
text: Ugh, don't call me that either. Who even came up with that nickname?

speaker: Judith
text: It's a perfect title for a boy who loves crafty schemes as much as you do. You should be grateful to the professor. On your own, you'd look like a scoundrel of a leader.

speaker: Hilda
text: Haha! Claude's usually so flippant, but even he gets overwhelmed when Judith is around!

speaker: Lorenz
text: As expected from the leader of the prestigious House Daphnel. Her dignity if beyond compare, even if she is no longer one of the Five Great Lords.

speaker: Byleth
text: The Five Great Lords?

speaker: Byleth
text: The prestigious House Daphnel?

speaker: Lorenz
text: The five most influential lords of the Leicester Alliance. They hold the voting rights at the roundtable conferences. House Daphnel used to be included among their ranks, but division from within has hastened their decline. Their vote has since been passed to the emerging Margrave Edmund.

speaker: Judith
text: Thanks for the exposition, Gloucester boy.

speaker: Lorenz
text: Boy?! I will not-

speaker: Judith
text: Now to business. There were some unexpected interruptions, but I've brought soldiers and supplies, as promised.

speaker: Claude
text: Thanks, Judith. I'll gladly take them off your hands...

speaker: Judith
text: Hold your horses, boy. You're misunderstanding. These soldiers are precious to me. I made them what they are. I'm not about to loan them out to someone.

speaker: Claude
text: No? Then why did you come here?!

speaker: Judith
text: What I'm saying is that I'll be joining your army. You're going to fight the Empire with the Knights of Seiros, right? Fight for Lady Rhea? Not without me.

speaker: Claude
text: That's admirable and all, but we still don't know for sure if Rhea is in the-

speaker: Judith
text: Oh, she's there. A witness saw Lady Rhea being dragged off by the Imperial army after the battle five years ago.

speaker: Alois
text: Are you sure your source is reliable?!

speaker: Judith
text: One of my own saw it happen. I'm certain.

speaker: Alois
text: It seems we chose wisely when we decided to fight against the Empire.

speaker: Claude
text: But you're the leader of House Daphnel. Is it OK for you to leave your territory unattended?

speaker: Judith
text: And what about you? Is it OK for you to leave the Riegan territory unattended?

speaker: Claude
text: That's... I've left it in the hands of a reliable retainer and-

speaker: Judith
text: And I've asked that retainer to watch over Daphnel territory as well.

speaker: Claude
text: Wait, wait, wait... You just up and decided to get my retainer to do that without even asking me? No respect, this one...

speaker: Byleth
text: What retainer?

speaker: Judith
text: Oh? You haven't met him yet, Professor? His name is Nardel. He strikes me as a really special individual. And he's quite handsome too!

speaker: Claude
text: So that's your definition of handsome?

speaker: Judith
text: No objections, then? Good. That settles it. House Daphnel is now yours to command.

speaker: Claude
text: I'm sure you'd come along even if I refused. So be it. We'll be counting on you, Judith.

speaker: Claude
text: With Judith joining our forces, we've secured some more troops and supplies... albeit not many.

speaker: Judith
text: Hmph. I'm sorry it couldn't be more.

speaker: Claude
text: No, it's enough for the time being. We'll use them to secure even more troops and supplies.

speaker: Byleth
text: How so?

speaker: Byleth
text: You think we can do that?

speaker: Claude
text: The key to my plan is Count Gloucester, the leader of the pro-Empire faction in the Alliance.

speaker: Lorenz
text: You intend to sway my father to join the other side?

speaker: Claude
text: If Count Gloucester were to switch to the other side, that would basically unify the Alliance. Then we could utilize our full military force in the fight against the Empire.

speaker: Lorenz
text: You don't mean to ask me to persuade him, do you? That would be... quite impossible.

speaker: Claude
text: I don't plan on it. We'll just take his concerns out of the equation. The Airmid River flows along the border between Gloucester territory and the Empire, right? Of all the bridges that cross it, the Great Bridge of Myrddin is the only one near Gloucester territory large enough for an army. Currently, the Imperial army occupies it.

speaker: Lysithea
text: So, if we were to capture the bridge...

speaker: Claude
text: Count Gloucester would be freed from the threat of the Empire. Thanks to us.

speaker: Lysithea
text: But we have to pass through Gloucester territory to reach the Great Bridge of Myrddin, do we not?

speaker: Claude
text: Yes. And if we attempted it, naturally he would try to stop us.

speaker: Lorenz
text: I am sorry, but I must ask. Surely you do not plan to engage in combat with my father?

speaker: Claude
text: Don't worry. I want him as a future ally. What good would it do to waste both of our forces fighting?

speaker: Byleth
text: I take it you have a scheme?

speaker: Claude
text: Who do you think you're taking to, Teach? Preparations are in the works even now.

speaker: Byleth
text: So, we'll be sneaking through?

speaker: Claude
text: We can't be stealthy with so many people. But I have a scheme. Preparations are already in the works.

speaker: Judith
text: So the Master Tactician is finally going to show us his true power. I'm looking forward to it!

speaker: Claude
text: I'll do my best to live up to that name by making my scheme as impressive as possible.

speaker: Claude
text: I just don't get it...

speaker: Leonie
text: What is it, Claude?

speaker: Claude
text: Those javelins of light... They were trying to use it to kill us at Fort Merceus, right? But then why not drop it on Garreg Mach? They must have known for a while that we were here.

speaker: Rhea
text: It is not that they chose to refrain, but rather that they were unable to do so.

speaker: Claude
text: Rhea! How are you feeling?

speaker: Rhea
text: I am well enough... I cannot afford to rest while Fódlan is in danger.

speaker: Claude
text: What do you mean when you say they couldn't drop a javelin of light here?

speaker: Rhea
text: Once, a very long time ago, a massive ball of light fell upon this monastery. However, that light mysteriously changed course in mid-air and landed in Ailell instead.

speaker: Leonie
text: Ailell, the Valley of Torment... So that's what the wreckage of those javelins of light looks like.

speaker: Rhea
text: The Holy Tomb is not only the location of the progenitor god's eternal slumber, but also a sacred vessel for a power that repels evil. Supposedly, the progenitor god built the Holy Tomb herself to protect her children from the evil light.

speaker: Claude
text: So the children of the goddess gathered in Zanado because of its proximity to the monastery? But we've fought at distant locations many times.

speaker: Leonie
text: Despite that, the javelins of light only fell on Fort Merceus.

speaker: Judith
text: In his letter, Hubert said that he detected their magic when the fort fell. In other words, because they used a javelin of light, Hubert was able to pinpoint the location of their base.

speaker: Leonie
text: So they didn't use it before then because they didn't want us to know where their base is?

speaker: Claude
text: In any case, those javelins of light must be something they can't just use whenever they want. And they finally decided to use one at Merceus, where they were sure they'd be able to finish us off. It's only thanks to the whims of the Death Knight that we escaped with our lives. And no javelins of light have fallen since then.

speaker: Judith
text: It's possible that the enemy hasn't yet realized that we've learned the location of their base.

speaker: Claude
text: If so, their guard may be down, which makes this the perfect time for a surprise attack.

speaker: Rhea
text: I will accompany you.

speaker: Seteth
text: What?! No! That would be far too dangerous! Your long confinement weakened you greatly, did it not?

speaker: Rhea
text: Those people have opposed us since ancient times. I wish to learn the truth about them for myself.

speaker: Seteth
text: I... I understand. I will not stop you, but please take care not to overexert yourself.

speaker: Claude
text: We don't know exactly what we're up against here, but having you around is very reassuring, Rhea. Let's prepare to strike at Shambhala before they make their next move!

speaker: Claude
text: We crushed the Empire at long last... But there's no time to bask in our victory. We must prepare for the coming battle. We knew there was a secret group behind the Imperial army all this time. Now, we have a chance to make the first move against them. We have Hubert to thank for that. It's also thanks to him that we were able to rescue Rhea. I still have plenty of questions I'd like to ask her.

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you going to see her?

speaker: Claude
text: Well, if we plan to have her march into battle with us again, we'd better let her recuperate.

speaker: Byleth
text: We should let her rest.

speaker: Claude
text: Rhea is the only one who gets a break, though. Everyone else had better start preparing for battle.

speaker: Lorenz
text: A mysterious power, threatening the very future of Fódlan? Certainly we cannot give it leeway. In comparison to this, the internal power struggles in the Alliance are utterly trivial.

speaker: Byleth
text: Aren't you frightened?

speaker: Lorenz
text: Fear will serve no purpose here. The only path to survival is victory.

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you think we can defeat it?

speaker: Lorenz
text: There is simply no option but victory! The alternative is unthinkable.

speaker: Lorenz
text: Perhaps I will have the opportunity to strike the decisive blow on the enemy commander. That would secure my place in history for certain!

speaker: Raphael
text: Wake up, eat, train, eat, train, eat, sleep. We gotta prepare for the assault, but that hasn't changed my routine!

speaker: Byleth
text: You're doing plenty.

speaker: Byleth
text: Isn't there more you can do?

speaker: Raphael
text: All the training... and eating... I do is for the sake of Fódlan! Gotta stay strong... and fed... to keep it safe!

speaker: Ignatz
text: Our next opponent is an ally of Solon. Do you remember what Solon called us?

speaker: Byleth
text: Traitors?

speaker: Ignatz
text: No. He called us beasts.

speaker: Byleth
text: Beasts?

speaker: Ignatz
text: That's right. He called us beasts.

speaker: Byleth
text: Insects?

speaker: Ignatz
text: No. He called us beasts.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Meanwhile, he refers to himself as the Savior. Who exactly is he saving?

speaker: Lysithea
text: Those who slither in the dark... It seems we'll finally discover their true form. I get the sense that they're in league with the mages who experimented on me as a child. I wouldn't be surprised if Edelgard was subjected to them too. There's no telling what their true motives are. But whatever their motives, what they have done is unforgivable. They must be exterminated.

speaker: Marianne
text: I thought the war would end with Edelgard's defeat... But that wasn't the case. This may be premature, but I'm feeling a little relieved. I have to consider what I'll do with myself and where I'll go when this war is finally over... I don't have an answer yet... Let's make sure the next battle puts an end to this war. That way we can all move forward!

speaker: Hilda
text: Shambhala it was called, right? Scary that it's so close to the House Goneril territories. Who'd have thought all those creeps were living right under my nose? I was hoping my big brother would help us in this next battle. But he says that I can represent House Goneril without his help. That I have it in me. I'm glad he recognizes that I have some ability. Still, I wish he wasn't leaving it all to me.

speaker: Leonie
text: These are Monica's people, aren't they? The ones who killed Captain Jeralt. Then this is my real opportunity for revenge. There's no way I can back down from this one.

speaker: Byleth
text: You're not scared?

speaker: Leonie
text: No, I'm OK. Actually, I'm eager to get our there and fight. This is what I've been training for.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wonder if we can win.

speaker: Leonie
text: If we lose, it's the end for Fódlan. So we have to win, even if it kills us.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: The history of the Empire spans 1185 years. And just like that, it ends. But the Hresvelg legacy could live on... When Edelgard assumed power, there were no other rightful heirs. She said that whoever takes the throne next should do so by virtue of merit, not blood. And she truly meant what she said. At any rate, I feel that a huge hole has opened up in my heart. Who knows if it can ever be filled?

speaker: Linhardt
text: As history proves, everything comes to an end eventually. I knew that all along, but it still came as a surprise. Those who slither in the dark... It's all so fascinating and strange. They must certainly have a long history of their own. And when they fall, that will come quickly too. Don't you think? Heh, that almost sounded like a prophecy there. Am I spooking you yet?

speaker: Caspar
text: He's dead... My father's dead... I'm OK though. Really. I was ready for it. He was a general in the Imperial army, after all. Minister of Military Affairs... He gave his own life so the Empire's soldiers wouldn't have to lose theirs. That's a fight that only he could take on. He was such a tough guy. This whole time I fought side by side with you and Claude... But did I ever get any stronger? Will I ever be as strong as my father?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: With Edelgard gone, maybe Fódlan will finally find some peace. That's all well and good, but, um... She was also the one to put my father under house arrest, so now he's been released, and he's taken charge of House Varley. I can't handle it! I can't deal with him! Please, you have to do something!

speaker: Byleth
text: How about we exile him?

speaker: Byleth
text: We can put him back under arrest.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Thank you so much!

speaker: Dorothea
text: So, the moment we defeat Edie, the nobles cozy up to the Alliance and church... That lot really does think only of themselves, and no one else. But then there's Count Bergliez. He used to be Minister of Military Affairs... He sacrificed his own life so that all the soldiers and officers who fought could be given quarter... When I heard that... I don't know... that simple act of humanity... I couldn't help it. I burst into tears. You know Count Bergliez is Casper's father, right? I can't even imagine how Caspar must feel about it.

speaker: Petra
text: The Empire has broken in... in smithereens. Now it is possible for me to go back to Brigid. But... I cannot choose that choice. The time is still too soon for that. We must be stopping the evil for everyone in Fódlan. We will be fighting until the end of it!

speaker: Felix
text: I thought that after the Empire fell, the boar might finally be avenged... But something dark is certainly lurking in the shadows - an organization behind the Empire. We'll have to take care of them if the boar... if Dimitri is to rest in peace.

speaker: Ashe
text: We've all heard the legend of Nemesis, the King of Liberation. But now Lady Rhea is saying Nemesis was just some kind of thief. Those two descriptions are totally at odds. Which version's correct? I don't know what to think. But I guess that's the nature of history. I wonder what the generations that come after us will say about the battle we're about to fight.

speaker: Sylvain
text: This war might be over but not war in general. Human beings thrive on conflict. We can't get enough of it. I don't know when, but you know someday another war will begin.

speaker: Byleth
text: Even so...

speaker: Sylvain
text: Heh heh... That's the way it is, right?

speaker: Byleth
text: You're probably right about that.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Yeah, but the fight is still worth it.

speaker: Sylvain
text: War may always come back but so will peace. And peace is what we fight for.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Lady Rhea still seems weak... but at least she's safe now. I'm praying that she'll be well as soon as possible. Goddess... I beg you... Protect Lady Rhea!

speaker: Annette
text: Finally, that awful war is over. Everyone lost something, and everyone had to make sacrifices... But maybe we can put a stop to all of this pain and loss now. Let's hurry to Shambhala, Professor! We have to defeat them if we ever want to see a world without war.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Is it really prudent to bring Lady Rhea on our upcoming expedition? It would be best not to have her doing anything strenuous, considering how long she was confined...

speaker: Byleth
text: It's her decision, ultimately.

speaker: Byleth
text: I feel similarly.

speaker: Ingrid
text: There are still many in Fódlan who are seeking Lady Rhea's salvation.

speaker: Seteth
text: Rhea is sleeping right now. If it is not absolutely urgent, please do not disturb her rest. The long confinement took its toll on her health. Truthfully, she is in no shape to be exerting herself at all – to say nothing of a military expedition. To make matters worst, we are now facing a very old enemy. One that has conspired against us since time out of mind. Please proceed with caution. I have a bad feeling.

speaker: Flayn
text: I am so glad that Rhea is unharmed. My brother continues to worry about her, however. Of course, I am worried myself. I cannot imagine being in that situation while in such a state... She should just leave things to you and Claude and get the rest she needs...

speaker: Hanneman
text: A mysterious organization, slithering in the dark of Fódlan... Like something out of a midnight tale. It appears these fiends have infiltrated the deepest corners of the Empire. After the fall of Enbarr, they've remained well concealed... That said, I would keep an eye on Edelgard's uncle, Lord Arundel. Something about him sits ill with me.

speaker: Manuela
text: Professor! Most of the opera company fled, but they’re back in the capital now. I don’t know if everyone survived, but it looks like they should be able to mount a revival. They even asked if I’d consider making a return to the stage someday... I suspect I may refuse though. We’re at the dawn of something new. No reason to look backwards, eh?

speaker: Alois
text: You've done it. You did it. You crushed the Empire, and rescued Lady Rhea. I'm sure the captain is proud of you right now. As am I, of course! I'm as proud as if I'd done it myself!

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's not celebrate just yet.

speaker: Byleth
text: We still have opponents left to fight.

speaker: Alois
text: Sorry. I didn't mean to overdo it. We still have Monica's group… Those who killed the captain. We'll knock 'em down so hard that they can't get back up!

speaker: Catherine
text: We rescued Lady Rhea! I can hardly express my joy. But now we know about a new foe, who intends to bring her harm. In time, we'll realize the peaceful world that Lady Rhea has always hoped for. I'll have to keep that in mind when I'm fighting.

speaker: Shamir
text: We saved Rhea and the Empire has crumbled. The Kingdom may as well be finished too. The reasons for me to remain in Fódlan are fading.

speaker: Byleth
text: Please, stay with us a little longer.

speaker: Shamir
text: Of course. I've come this far. May as well see it through to the end.

speaker: Byleth
text: Is it time to bid farewell?

speaker: Shamir
text: That's a little hasty. I've come this far. May as well see it through to the end.

speaker: Cyril
text: Lady Rhea’s back! Lady Rhea’s back! I’m so happy! But... things aren’t gonna be like they used to be any time soon, are they? There’s still folks out there who want us all dead, and Lady Rhea still hasn’t regained her strength yet. Speaking of which, Professor, please don’t ask too much of her right now, OK?

speaker: Judith
text: The folks we're fighting next aren't normal humans, are they? It's that group who caused the javelin of light to fall, right? It just doesn't seem like something a human is capable of. I'm not prone to flinching, but I don't feel great about any of this...

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! I can hardly believe you managed to handle the capital city like that. Everyone did sterling work! I really thought we'd know peace after the battle. But we're not quite there yet, huh?

speaker: Lysithea
text: Incredible… Who knew that there was such a vast space beneath the ground…

speaker: Judith
text: It's like an underground city. I've never seen buildings like these before.

speaker: Lysithea
text: It's like an ancient ruin… But not just because of its appearance.

speaker: Ignatz
text: I don't recall ever seeing architecture like this.

speaker: Lorenz
text: It is magnificent in a sense, but I could hardly call it beautiful, Even the air feels stagnant.

speaker: Claude
text: In any case, it seems like we need to go further. Let's look around and see if we can find some stairs.

speaker: Byleth
text: Something on your mind?

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you not feeling well?

speaker: Rhea
text: No. It is simply… We must defeat those who slither in the dark, no matter what happens. But if my conjecture is correct, the one who they will wish to kill the most…

speaker: Rhea
text: Is you, dear child.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why me?

speaker: Rhea
text: They are aware that you can use the Sword of the Creator. Your body houses the same power they once bestowed upon Nemesis. That is why…I fear for you.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's not much to go on.

speaker: Rhea
text: Perhaps. Please forgive my errant thoughts. Once this battle is over… I will explain everything. I will tell you all I know about who you really are.

speaker: Thales
text: For thousands of years, we have existed underground, living on only that we might someday see our vengeance realized. Here and now, that vengeance is finally within our grasp. There is but one thing left to do. Destroy them! Damn those who stand with that arrogant goddess to oblivion, away from the world of the living!

speaker: Thales
text: Now is the time. Remove the binding spell of Titanus. Let their metal bodies be drenched in blood!

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, what are those big…things?

speaker: Rhea
text: Demonic Beasts… No, I think not. They appear to have no will of their own. Someone must be controlling them.

speaker: Thales
text: Initiate all that remain! We must advance our preparations!

speaker: Thales
text: Viskam has been activated? Increase output gradually, depending on the amount of magical energy charged. I don't care if we destroy Shambhala, as long as our goals are fulfilled!

speaker: Rhea
text: Those awful weapons have been stopped. They were being controlled from that facility!

speaker: Claude
text: Aw, those big things have gone to sleep on us. That will make moving around a lot easier. A dead end? Or perhaps... No, if we worry about every little detail, we won't get anywhere.

speaker: Thales
text: You!

speaker: Rhea
text: That is the leader of those who slither in the dark. We must go after him with all our might!

speaker: Claude
text: It seems someone is trying to remove something. We’d better capture them first!

speaker: Thales
text: You’re nothing but animals performing tricks in the hopes of pleasing the goddess. You will never see the sunlight again!

speaker: Thales
text: So you have shown yourself, Fell Star. Or, should I say…Sothis? I will spill every drop of blood in your body to fulfill the longstanding goal of the Agarthans!

speaker: Thales
text: Your eyes, hair, ears, and blood…We remember it all. We remember how you ruined us. How you stole our light and condemned us to eternal darkness! Now, suffer the wrath of the Agarthans!

speaker: Thales
text: Ha. It is laughable that base animals such as you would bare fangs at the likes of us.

speaker: Claude
text: I may be a base animal, but I have strong allies. Do you think you can beat Teach and the Sword of the Creator?

speaker: Thales
text: The Sword of the Creator… The blade given to Nemesis. Who do you really think is superior?

speaker: Claude
text: There’s a big difference between the living and the dead. The fate of the future lies in the hands of the living!

speaker: Thales
text: You will never get to enjoy your victory.

speaker: Rhea
text: It can't be...

speaker: Thales
text: For all Agarthans... Let there be light!

speaker: Soldier
text: It's coming down!

speaker: Nemesis
text: Seiros...

speaker: Rhea
text: Ugh…

speaker: Cyril
text: Hang in there, Lady Rhea.

speaker: Catherine
text: Get her to her room, quickly!

speaker: Manuela
text: That's a serious injury… It's a miracle that she's even alive right now. I'll do what I can, but…

speaker: Marianne
text: Goddess… Please save Lady Rhea…

speaker: Hilda
text: All we can do now is pray…

speaker: Claude
text: Remember when this place was taken five years ago, and a pure White Beast appeared on the battlefield? I only caught a glimpse of it, but I didn't understand where it came from. There were rumors that the goddess sent it to protect the monastery… But now I know better. That beast was Rhea.

speaker: Byleth
text: She tried to save me…

speaker: Claude
text: Did you know Rhea's true identity?

speaker: Byleth
text: Looking back on it now, I suppose I did.

speaker: Claude
text: I once showed you a picture of a creature known as the Immaculate One. Seteth confiscated it, saying it must have been one of Tomas' personal possessions. The beast that appeared back then looked just like it. So Rhea is the Immaculate One. The book said it was a servant of the goddess, but wouldn't it make sense if beasts like that are actually children of the goddess?

speaker: Claude
text: Rhea is in a grim state right now. It's possible she may not make it. But we have things we must ask her about. Once things calm down a little, let's go and see Rhea. Together. The truth can't be delayed any longer.

speaker: Claude
text: All of that went about as well as it could have. Each lord has agreed to provide us with soldiers and supplies.

speaker: Judith
text: I'm impressed you were able to convince all of those scattered nobles to help us. I thought they would quarrel about how much support they should each provide. That's what they usually do.

speaker: Claude
text: Well, Count Gloucester took the initiative in taking on responsibilities. I presume that was because you spoke with him in advance, Lorenz?

speaker: Lorenz
text: I merely explained the situation at hand, then my father simply followed your lead, Claude. It was because you had the professor there to represent Lady Rhea. My father is a pious follower of the Church of Seiros.

speaker: Claude
text: I don't doubt it. I wasn't under the delusion that it was my personal charm that unified everyone. Thanks for that, by the way. I hope you don't feel like I used you... because I sort of used you.

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't mention it.

speaker: Claude
text: I appreciate that. We don't have time to be picky about our methods. But be honest. You're having a hard time adjusting to your new role, aren't you?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not well pleased.

speaker: Claude
text: I understand. You're having a hard time adjusting to your new role, aren't you? You weren't even a follower of Seiros to being with, and somehow you've ended up as a representative of the church.

speaker: Claude
text: I realize that you might feel guilty about deceiving the believers for our cause...

speaker: Shamir
text: I have news. Our enemy is gathering troops at Fort Merceus. Their army is immense. Likely led by a renowned general. Or perhaps even...

speaker: Byleth
text: Edelgard?

speaker: Claude
text: Well now, that would be interesting. If we can defeat the emperor, then the Empire will collapse.

speaker: Byleth
text: The Flame Emperor?

speaker: Claude
text: Perhaps. But she's more than that now. She's the actual emperor. If we can defeat her, the Empire will collapse.

speaker: Judith
text: There's something else. An unidentified army has approached the Great Bridge of Myrddin. They passed through the Daphnel and Gloucester territories from the northwest with incredible speed. They're raising the banner of House Blaiddyd. Perhaps they are the remnants of the Faerghus royal family. From what we could tell, they posed no threat to the citizens of the Alliance, and so we refrained from engaging them in needless combat.

speaker: Claude
text: Maybe they hope to fight against the Empire to avenge their fallen prince. And what about the bridge itself?

speaker: Judith
text: Obviously we wouldn't let them pass without receiving envoys first. We thought they may try to force their way through. We considered firing warning arrows, but they left immediately, heading east.

speaker: Claude
text: Are they intending to use one of the bridges in Ordelia territory?

speaker: Judith
text: Most likely. But the Imperial army still controls those bridges. I can't imagine what they intend to do in the Empire, even if they do manage to break through...

speaker: Claude
text: I'm reluctant to ease up on our surveillance, but it would be difficult to track them there... For now, let's assume they're just troops belonging to the old Kingdom. In any case, we should proceed with caution. Soon, we'll be entering Empire territory ourselves. If our enemies are going to intercept us with an attack... It will probably be at Gronder Field... How fitting that it was the site of the Battle of the Eagle and Lion five years ago.

speaker: Claude
text: We secured the win in our first skirmish, but the next battle is a different matter. The Empire will come after us with everything it's got. Even so, the ultimate victory will be ours. And I'm not just saying that! I've made ample preparations to ensure our victory. It's my rule to never leave victory to chance. You can't rely on the protection of the goddess. With your power and my schemes, I should be able to plot a direct course to victory.

speaker: Lorenz
text: House Gloucester has changed it's allegiance and joined the faction that is against the Empire. The Alliance will thus remain united. But thanks to this latest ploy, my father is more suspicious of Claude now than ever. If such a thing is possible. Ordinarily, I might credit his helpful posture towards us to his devout faith in the Church of Seiros. But it is clear to me now that this is nothing more than a shrewd calculation on his part. He is only thinking of his position. We are in the clear for now, but please bear in mind that the Alliance is never an entirely stable union.

speaker: Raphael
text: I gotta say, it's tough to keep the fighting spirit alive when you recognize your enemies on the battlefield.

speaker: Raphael
text: It's like when we were fighting before... I saw Lorenz and wasn't sure what to do with myself.

speaker: Byleth
text: Everyone gets that feeling.

speaker: Raphael
text: So you can't avoid it, huh? How did everything get so messed up?

speaker: Byleth
text: You can run away if you want.

speaker: Raphael
text: Hey, come on! Even I know we can't do that!

speaker: Raphael
text: Just because we're fighting someone doesn't mean we gotta hate 'em! That's probably the worst thing about war. Win or lose, I still get a bad taste in my mouth.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Thanks to our victory, I've been able to study the Great Bridge of Myrddin at my leisure. And you know what? It's an astounding structure. So much history there. Imagine how much time and effort it must have taken to build something that big. Over water, no less! I hope that someday it will be opened up to the people of Fódlan - a historical site, rather than a military checkpoint.

speaker: Lysithea
text: I trust you and Claude, but I feel uneasy. If we lose in the next battle, the Empire's army will likely come surging into Alliance territory. If that happens, my parents won't escape unharmed. They've raised their anti-Imperial flag, after all.

speaker: Byleth
text: I won't let that happen.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Thank you, Professor. I'll fight with all I've got too.

speaker: Byleth
text: We can't take back what we've done.

speaker: Lysithea
text: You're right. I chose my path. I must press on. That's all anyone can do, really.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Speaking with you has eased my mind a bit. Just enough in fact, to put me in the mood for sweets.

speaker: Marianne
text: I've been praying to the goddess for Lorenz... We wouldn't have had to fight like that if things were different.

speaker: Marianne
text: Um, I heard that some unidentified troops have appeared, but... Apparently they were flying the flag of the Faerghus royal family... Do you think it was Dimitri's ghost? His country was taken before he ever wore the crown. Surely he must regret that...

speaker: Hilda
text: Poor Lorenz. He and I weren't very close, but we were friends.

speaker: Hilda
text: Claude was saying that our next battle might be in Gronder Field. Is that right? Reminds me of the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. But of course, that was a very different time. When it was over, all three class heads complimented each other on their bravery. And then we had a party. But we can never go back to that, can we?

speaker: Leonie
text: We might see Edelgard herself leading the enemy in the next battle. If they're coming out of Fort Merceus, our troops might even clash on Gronder Field. And those other troops on the march - who knows what they'll do, or what side they'll take? Not sure how we're supposed to form a strategy with so many unknowns.

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't worry. I can handle it.

speaker: Leonie
text: I don't know why you're so confident, but it does somehow make me feel better.

speaker: Byleth
text: As long as you're here, I'll be fine.

speaker: Leonie
text: Hey, how come you only ever flatter me in times like these? What am I supposed to make of that?

speaker: Leonie
text: Anyways, we've come this far. Let's just keep putting one foot in front of the other and see how far we get.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: We captured the Great Bridge of Myrddin, but the fight has only just begun. Enbarr, the Imperial Capital, lies far to the south, beyond Gronder Field. And waiting on the way there is the entire Imperial army, with twice as many troops as us. We had better brace ourselves.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I seem to lack the skills required to grieve for the dead. If someone has passed, even someone dear to me, I could stand about and wail or get on with my life. While I'm at it, that whole idea that we must speak well of the dead? I don't understand that either. If I didn't like them when they were alive, then why pretend to do so when they are no longer here?

speaker: Caspar
text: After we cross the Great Bridge of Myrddin, we'll be in my father's territory. We actually crossed it five years ago for the Battle of Eagle and Lion. Remember? Ugh! This is terrifying! What am I gonna do? I gotta get a grip...

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't worry, I'll arrange for your funeral.

speaker: Caspar
text: You think we'll meet him on the battlefield and he'll kill me? The front lines cover a long stretch of land, you know! We might not even run into him!

speaker: Byleth
text: I'll pray for your safety.

speaker: Caspar
text: Oh, no no no. You should pray we don't run into him at all! The front lines cover a long stretch of land, you know!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: So the campaign continues, does it? Well, allow me, as a professional recluse with ten years of experience, to volunteer for, um...staying behind. Oh, who am I kidding? The fighting won't stop until we've defeated Edelgard, will it? Or until we lose, I guess. But there's not much use in thinking about that.

speaker: Dorothea
text: The Great Bridge of Myrddin was considerably better fortified than it was five years ago... The bridge was full of soldiers...and they all died.

speaker: Dorothea
text: And Ferdie was there. We killed Ferdie, Professor, he used to be our friend. Do you remember those days?

speaker: Petra
text: Nobles who are changing allegiance, again and again. I do not have understanding for that. How can you trust if treason comes with ease? How can you be calling yourself a noble? I do not have understanding of the reasoning...

speaker: Byleth
text: They're struggling for survival too.

speaker: Petra
text: Surviving is more difficult without trust. There must be...some other goal.

speaker: Byleth
text: For personal gain.

speaker: Petra
text: Survival has more importance than that. Are they not knowing this?

speaker: Felix
text: So, the boar prince is dead. Decapitated, I hear. I haven't seen the severed head myself. Perhaps he's still alive and leading that army...

speaker: Byleth
text: Would you be able to fight him?

speaker: Felix
text: Don't patronize me. If his head is still attached to his body, I'll remedy that without hesitation.

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't get distracted.

speaker: Felix
text: You're right. I can't let my emotions take hold.

speaker: Felix
text: Either way, a major battle awaits us. Try not to die. I'll be annoyed if you did.

speaker: Ashe
text: If we defeat the Imperial army at Gronder Field, what will our next objective be? I guess we won't have much choice but to try to take Fort Merceus, on the far side of Gronder Field. It's probably too soon for us to be thinking about that, isn't it? The battle just ahead of us is far from certain.

speaker: Sylvain
text: The time’s come to fight the Empire, huh? Wow, it’s shaping up to be quite the battle. And I’ve got no problem with that, but that mystery army really worries me. There’s no indication if they’re friend or foe… Who do you think they are, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: Remnants of the old Kingdom?

speaker: Sylvain
text: I suppose it’s possible. After all, His Highness is supposedly dead.

speaker: Byleth
text: Dimitri himself?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Heh, not unless he rose from the grave to secure revenge. That would mean… Actually, I have no idea what that would mean.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Well, whoever they are, I hope we can avoid fighting them.

speaker: Mercedes
text: So, we're finally going to set foot in the Empire...I'm starting to get a little nervous.

speaker: Mercedes
text: We already fought Ferdinand at the Great Bridge of Myrddin, but...

speaker: Mercedes
text: I guess there's a good chance we'll be fighting more old friends from here on out.

speaker: Annette
text: Claude seems filled with confidence, but I wonder if everything really will be OK… The Imperial army might be hiding the emperor, and the troops headed south might belong to the old Kingdom. I’ll be honest… I’m incredibly uneasy about all this. But at this point there’s…no option but to move forward.

speaker: Ingrid
text: I’ve cut all contact with my family since joining this fight. Were I to see soldiers of the Galatea Family amidst the host flying the royal family’s banner… I… Well. All chance of reconciliation with my father would end there. I do not know if that is the right path. But, the fact is, I’ve come this far. There’s no time for second guessing. Not anymore.

speaker: Seteth
text: Each time we press forward, our search for Rhea broadens to a wider area. I certainly hope we will find at least some clue, but I do suspect I already know where she is. If I am right, and she is in the Imperial capital, then we cannot save her until we topple the Empire.

speaker: Flayn
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion. Has it truly been five years since then? Can you recall whether it was before or after I joined your class, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: Before.

speaker: Flayn
text: That is not at all the case, Professor. Your memory serves you poorly.

speaker: Byleth
text: After.

speaker: Flayn
text: I'm glad you have not forgotten.

speaker: Flayn
text: It was shortly after I joined your class - I remember it like it was yesterday.

speaker: Hanneman
text: When undertaking research, the usual methods is to form a hypothesis, then test it with experiments. Those experiments reveal facts and falsehoods, yet sometimes, they also unveil an exception. You seem to be that exception when it comes to my Crest research.

speaker: Byleth
text: Sorry about that.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't understand.

speaker: Hanneman
text: Worry not, Professor. Exceptions are what make my work interesting. Why don't the rules apply to you? I will find our eventually. I feel it is my destiny as a Crest scholar!

speaker: Manuela
text: I hear the next battle could be a big one, is that true? I miss the old days when, if someone got hurt, we'd rush them to the infirmary, and make them well... But on the battlefield, there's not enough time to help. People die. Professor, don't be one of those!

speaker: Alois
text: Word just reached me that the Empire has stationed soldiers in Fort Merceus. If they decide to dig in their heels and defend the fort, we'll be in a difficult situation. I hear it's an impregnable keep, surrounded by high ramparts. Taking it would not be easy.

speaker: Catherine
text: Beyond the Great Bridge of Myrddin, it's all unfamiliar territory for us. We don't know where Lady Rhea is being held. We ought to investigate all potential locations thoroughly. The Knights of Seiros will handle the search. We'll report back if we learn anything.

speaker: Shamir
text: Reconnaissance is becoming more of a risk the deeper we move into enemy territory. If I don't come back, assume I'm dead.

speaker: Byleth
text: I know you won't get caught.

speaker: Shamir
text: I'm glad you think so highly of me, but we have to be realistic.

speaker: Byleth
text: Understood.

speaker: Shamir
text: Good. We have to be realistic.

speaker: Shamir
text: Don't waste your energy worrying about me.

speaker: Cyril
text: I gotta keep this place clean, and I mean properly clean, every day. Dust it, sweep it, everything. You never can tell when Lady Rhea might be back.

speaker: Judith
text: Since little Claude became their leader, the Alliance lords haven't been especially unified. Now, they're suddenly united for a common cause. As a result, the Empire hasn't been able to perform even one successful incursion... Rather, we're the ones who might get the jump on them. It's incredible. Magical, even. Maybe his strategic genius was simmering for those five years, and it returned to a full boil once you two were reunited. Or maybe he always knew he'd meet you again, and he was preparing for that this whole time...

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! I hear we're sending troops to Gronder Field next. Is that what's what? That whole area is in the territory of House Bergliez. It's famous as the main granary of Fódlan. If we could capture it, we probably wouldn't have to worry about food anymore! Bread for all!

speaker: Hilda
text: Gronder Field should be around here, right? But it's so foggy... Even if there were enemies here, we'd never know it.

speaker: Lysithea
text: I recall the terrain from the Battle of the Eagle and Lion, but without the ability to see the enemy's formation...

speaker: Claude
text: Our enemies are subject to the same conditions. We'll just have to wait for the fog to clear up.

speaker: Judith
text: Speaking of enemies, what do you think became of those unidentified troops? Any follow-up reports?

speaker: Claude
text: We haven't heard anything since. If they were headed this way... Well, I'd like to avoid being caught by surprise, but we can't make use of our scouts because of this fog. It's hard to predict this fight. There's no way to know what will happen.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm worried.

speaker: Claude
text: We did everything we could to prepare. If we lose despite that, then we'll just have to accept it as fate and retreat.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's try to stay calm.

speaker: Claude
text: Of course. The morale of our allies would be crushed if we let them see us shaking in our boots.

speaker: Claude
text: Your guidance is going to be crucial, Teach. Now more than ever. Do whatever it takes to lead us to victory.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I will crush anyone who blocks my path.

speaker: Claude
text: Dimitri... He's alive. But he doesn't look interested in joining forces with us.

speaker: Edelgard
text: It would not be advantageous to take on both at once. We must stop the Kingdom and the Alliance from joining forces. I will create such chaotic warfare that they won't be able to tell who is friend and who is foe.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Mounted units, advance!

speaker: Imperial General
text: There are enemies in the central area... We need to head there immediately to protect it!

speaker: Petra
text: The center is in danger of being taken. We must be running to protect it!

speaker: Dimitri
text: The Imperial army is starting to crumble. We will step on the Empire right along with the Alliance troops. To the eternal flames with all of them!

speaker: Hubert
text: How kind of our enemies to fight one another. And open flanks as well? Generous.

speaker: Dimitri
text: If they're going to stand in our way, they must die. Smash them to pieces! It is time. Someone, take the central hill!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Those fools who went up the hill will pay with their lives... in the crimson flames!

speaker: Edelgard
text: This is not as I planned, but there's nothing to be done. Burn the central hill!

speaker: Hubert
text: The central hill is up in smoke. Suppose I'll have to quench the flames - with the enemy's blood.

speaker: Claude
text: Even in an ugly battle like this, it's important not to lose heart. We have to take pride in our victory. We did it, Teach. Now we can move forward. To our victory!

speaker: Felix
text: Want to die? Step forward. I'll take you all.

speaker: Felix
text: Not here... Not like this...

speaker: Dimitri
text: Felix...

speaker: Ingrid
text: We all choose our paths and I've chosen mine. I fight for my lord, to the death!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Your Highness... I... failed you...

speaker: Dimitri
text: Ingrid...

speaker: Sylvain
text: Huh. I guess this is fate. Sorry, but I need you to please give up quietly, OK?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Heh, I'm not afraid... I figured it would end like this.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh! I haven't seen you in so long! It's such a shame we have to meet like this...

speaker: Mercedes
text: I'm... I'm sorry, Dimitri... I can't seem to stay... on my feet.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Hmph...

speaker: Dedue
text: In the name of High Highness, you die here.

speaker: Dedue
text: I... can still fight, Your Highness.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Shut up and retreat. You must live, Dedue.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Are you trying to stop me too? Then I'll just have to kill you!

speaker: Dimitri
text: You're not worth it. Get out of my sight.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Where are you, Edelgard?! I will not stop until I kill you!

speaker: Claude
text: Calm down, Dimitri! What does it achieve, us killing each other here?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Move, Claude. I have no time to exchange words with you.

speaker: Claude
text: It doesn't matter what I'm saying, does it? You aren't even listening. But I'm not gonna budge.

speaker: Claude
text: So... Edelgard retreated. I suppose she lives to be defeated another day.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's fine.

speaker: Claude
text: I suppose a win is a win, regardless of the circumstances.

speaker: Byleth
text: It was close.

speaker: Claude
text: Too close. But I suppose all that matters is that we won.

speaker: Claude
text: Some of our allies are injured, but can still fight. We'll just have to accept this outcome and press onward. Still, the battlefield looks awful. And I wonder what became of the Kingdom army. And Dimitri...

speaker: Hilda
text: I saw him.

speaker: Claude
text: Who? Dimitri?

speaker: Hilda
text: He was completely different from how I remember him. He looked like a crazed demon while he was fighting. He pursued Edelgard as she retreated, but he didn't get far before he collapsed. I saw him surrounded by Imperial troops and... pierced by their spears. I'll never forget it. He deserved a better end.

speaker: Claude
text: Dimitri... He went through so much to make it here, only for his efforts to be in vain.

speaker: Hilda
text: I can't even begin to understand what Dimitri must have been feeling, but... There must have been some other way. Why did he have to go like that?

speaker: Claude
text: And his vassal, Dedue... Did he fall as well?

speaker: Hilda
text: I don't know...

speaker: Dedue
text: Your Highness! Your ambitions are my own now! I... I will bring you Edelgard's head... I swear it!

speaker: Lysithea
text: Professor? Claude? May I have a moment of your time?

speaker: Claude
text: Lysithea, what are you doing up this late? Trouble sleeping?

speaker: Byleth
text: That's understandable.

speaker: Byleth
text: We all have nights like that.

speaker: Claude
text: Anyone would be shaken after such a brutal battle. If you're having trouble sleeping, you should drink some warm milk. That's a thing, right?

speaker: Lysithea
text: Must you treat me like a child, simply because I am awake a bit later than usual? Actually, I can hardly muster any indignation right now. I wanted to tell you that I noticed something odd during that battle.

speaker: Claude
text: What was it?

speaker: Lysithea
text: There were some strange mages among the ranks of the Imperial army. Did you notice them?

speaker: Byleth
text: The ones wearing masks?

speaker: Byleth
text: The ones dressed in black?

speaker: Lysithea
text: That's right. I have seen people dressed just like that before. It was a long time ago... House Ordelia was involved in a rebellion that took place within the Empire 18 years ago. After it was quelled, all of the key officials were caught and put to death. The Empire sent replacements, who they used to take control of House Ordelia. Among the people sent by the Empire were mages dressed in black, just like those we saw in battle.

speaker: Claude
text: If they're Imperial mages, it would make sense that they would wear the same clothing, right?

speaker: Lysithea
text: Yes, but the mages from back then and today... I do not believe they are from the Adrestian Empire.

speaker: Byleth
text: Are they Kingdom mages?

speaker: Byleth
text: Are they Alliance mages?

speaker: Lysithea
text: No. I got the impression that they were from somewhere else. Somewhere completely separate from Fódlan. There's more. Those mages imprisoned the children from my house, and performed horrible rituals on them. Blood experiments.

speaker: Claude
text: Lysithea... You can't mean... even you?

speaker: Lysithea
text: Yes. All of the others were deemed failures. They all died. And even I... It doesn't matter. The point is, that those monsters possess dreadful knowledge and power. I just thought you should know the sort of people who have allied with the Empire.

speaker: Claude
text: Blood experiments... Does that remind you of anything, Teach?

speaker: Byleth
text: The incident with Flayn...

speaker: Byleth
text: That incident with the Flame Emperor...

speaker: Claude
text: Exactly. There was that secret group who abducted Flayn and extracted her blood five years ago. The people involved back then were Tomas and Monica... Well, I suppose their true names were Solon and Kronya. So that eerie group has been slithering behind the scenes in the Empire for a while now... Lysithea... Thank you for sharing all of that with us. One day we will uncover the truth of who those people really are.

speaker: Claude
text: We've managed to invade Empire territory and emerge victorious in our first battle. I hope to maintain our momentum and push onward to Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. Unfortunately, we are not legendary heroes in a fairytale. Our stamina has limits. The longer we fight, the harder the fight will become. It will take immense effort to secure the supplies and soldier we need to prevail.

speaker: Judith
text: Boy, you better not be saying this is as far as we go.

speaker: Claude
text: Of course not. However, the road ahead leads deep into enemy territory. It will be a difficult journey, strewn with hardship. I can't guarantee that we'll make it out alive. If anyone wants to leave, now is the time to do it.

speaker: Lorenz
text: I shall accompany you to the very end. After all, someone must step up to take leadership should you fall.

speaker: Leonie
text: I'm coming. The future of my village depends on this. Besides... I have to protect the professor. For Captain Jeralt.

speaker: Raphael
text: I'm not going anywhere! Because of the Empire, my little sis can't live in peace!

speaker: Ignatz
text: We can't leave the future of Fódlan to others. I'm sure that everyone here feels the same.

speaker: Alois
text: The Knights of Seiros will keep fighting the Empire. We won't rest until we rescue Lady Rhea.

speaker: Cyril
text: I feel the same as the knights. I've gotta rescue Lady Rhea no matter what.

speaker: Hilda
text: So, what - we're all supposed to take turns saying we'll do our best until the very end? And what about you, Marianne? What will you do?

speaker: Marianne
text: I... I'll fight too!

speaker: Hilda
text: Fine, fine. I suppose I'll tag along too... Until the bitter end.

speaker: Claude
text: It's an honor to keep fighting alongside such stalwart allies. Right, Teach?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'd expect nothing less from my students.

speaker: Claude
text: Hey now, when you put it that way, it almost sounds like you're just praising yourself!

speaker: Byleth
text: You're a stalwart ally too, Claude.

speaker: Claude
text: I know I'm a great leader and all, but praising me isn't gonna get you anywhere.

speaker: Claude
text: All right. Now that I know where each of you stands, I'm going to return to Alliance territory for a while. I intend to report this victory to Alliance lords and draw out even more support from them. Our next battle will be even more challenging, so brace yourselves for that.

speaker: Hilda
text: Hmm... I should write to my brother. He'll want to hear about our victory.

speaker: Claude
text: Your brother, Lord Holst? How is he these days?

speaker: Hilda
text: Oh, he's doing great. I even got a letter from him before the last battle. He wanted to come and join our fight too.

speaker: Lorenz
text: What's this? Lord Holst, come here? That would be a most reassuring development.

speaker: Hilda
text: Sadly, it sounds like my father was against the idea. They wanted him to stay in case they need to fight the Almyrans.

speaker: Lorenz
text: Their logic is sound. Though it is vexing that the Alliance's greatest general cannot join us on the front lines.

speaker: Claude
text: We should be glad that Holst is staying behind. Almyra aside, there's also no guarantee that the Imperial forces won't try to launch a surprise attack from the old Kingdom territory.

speaker: Hilda
text: Um... If you have something you need to talk to my brother about, I'd be happy to send a letter.

speaker: Claude
text: No, that's OK. I'm just glad to hear he's doing well. Please send him my regards.
